Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Expectation2: Greet clients and make them feel comfortable
Situation2: A nervous new client steps inside, glancing around the salon for direction.
Story: I was sitting on the worn couch in our living room, half-listening as my stepdad tossed out ideas for the weekend. My stepsister nudged me, her eyes bright with hope that I’d back her up on the movie night she wanted. I knew I should chime in, show I was part of the family, but my phone buzzed with a reminder: my next client was due in five minutes. I hurried to the salon, still thinking about the family plans, when the door chimed and a young woman stepped in, clutching her bag and scanning the room with anxious eyes. I was supposed to greet her warmly, help her relax, but my mind was split—should I text my stepsister to say I’d join the movie night, or focus on making this client feel welcome? My heart pounded as I stood between the reception desk and my phone, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in, unsure which one needed me more in that moment.
